_prev_prog_3.Description:
The ammonia neutralization process is a batch process in which phosphonates are neutralized with anhydrous ammonia (NH3) in a stirred tank, pressure vessel (reactor) and an atmospheric vessel (blend tank).  The ammonia flow to the reactors and blend vessels is controlled so that almost all of the ammonia is reacted.  Any excess ammonia is vented to the plant scrubber system, where it is absorbed.  Safety relief devices are installed on the reactor to prevent catastrophic failure of the reactor should an unlikely overpressurization occur.  Overpressurization is not possible on the atmospheric tanks, so no relief system is necessary on the blend vessels.
The major bulk of the ammonia onsite is in the storage tank.  The storage tank is a 250 psig rated pressure vessel.  Safety relief devices are also installed on the tank to prevent a rupture of the tank that might be caused by an overpressurization.  The ammonia pressure at all ambient temperature conditions is well below 200 psig.  An excess flow valve is also installed between the tank and the plant piping that will stop the flow of ammonia from the tank as a result of a pipe failure or an excessive flow rate to the reactor or blend tank.  Check valves are also installed in the ammonia delivery lines to the reactor to prevent backflow of potential contaminants to the storage vessel.
The loading of the storage tank from a delivery truck is accomplished by used of a closed loop vapor recycle system in which the liquid ammonia is pumped from the bottom of the tank truck by a compressor to the bottom of the storage tank, and the ammonia vapro from the top of the storage tank is recycled back to the tank truck so that no ammonia is exhausted to the atmosphere.  The plant operator and truck driver manage the following:  the connection of the truck to the storage vessel; the unloading of the truck; and the uncoupling of the truck from the storage tank.  The plant operators and truck drivers have been trained and are experienced in the safe handling of ammonia.
A process hazards analysis (PHA) has been conducted on the process from truck delivery to reactor operation and finished product.  Written operating procedures are in place to ensure on going integrity of the process equipment and piping.  Inspections include ultrasound thickness tests and visual inspection of glass lined reactors.  Leaking pumps, lines and valves are tagged and repaired by maintenance in a timely manner.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The bisulfite process is analagous to the ammonia neutralization process in that it is a batch process where sulfur dioxide (SO2) is reacted in a pressurized, stirred tank reactor.  The reactor is protected by safety relief devices from a potential catastrophic failure caused by overpressurization.  The difference between the bisulfite batch process and the ammonia neutralization batch process is that SO2 is acidic and ammonia is basic.
The SO2 addition (flow) to the reactor is controlled so that it is almost completely reacted.  The reactor is first purged with nitrogen (N2) to remove any oxygen prior to the addition of SO2.  Any excess SO2 remaining after the reaction is purged to the plant scrubber system by N2.  The plant scrubber system supresses emission of SO2 to the atmosphere.  N2 is also used to purge the SO2 delivery lines from the reactor back to the storage vessel.
Like the ammonia, the major amount of SO2 onsite is contained in the 250 psig rated storage vessel.  The SO2 is the storage tank is blanketed with N2 to exclude oxygen.  The N2 blanket pressure and ambient pressure of SO2 are well below the storage tank's rated pressure.  Like the reactor, the SO2 storage tank is protected from a potential catastrophic release by safety relief devices.  The tank is also inspected by an outside source every three years with the last inspection.
Like the ammonia tank, the SO2 storage tank is loaded from a delivery truck by the used of a closed loop recycle system between the storage tank and the delivery truck to prevent emissions of SO2 to the atmosphere.  Plant process operators, supervisors, and delivery truck drivers have been formally trained in the safe handling and loading and unloading of SO2.  Operator training is conducted on a yearly basis.  A process hazard analysis (PHA) has been conducted on the SO2 storage and bisulfite batch reaction systems.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary for Champion Technologies, Inc., Odessa Plant

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Champion Technologies, Inc. (Champion), Odessa Plant, has always had a strong commitment to its employees to provide a safe working environment.  This policy is consistent with both the spirit and the intent of our commitment.  The safety of employees, company operations, and the public are management's most important objectives.  Safety will take precedence over expediency or short cuts.  Champion intends to continue its complete compliance with all safety regulations and safety policies.

Every attempt will be made to reduce the possibility of accident occurrence by all levels of management.  Champion believes that safety, like quality and housekeeping, can be controlled by motivated supervision.  Therefore, preventable lost time accidents will have an impact on a supervisor's annual salary review, including any bonuses and incentive plans.  Unreported accidents will be considered falsification of company records and will result in immediate discharge.  Lost time accident free locations will be eligible for annual awards.

2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
Champion is a specialty chemical manufacturer of oilfield chemicals.  We have two regulated substances present at our facility as raw materials for our processes, which include anhydrous ammonia (NH3) and sulfur dioxide (SO2).  NH3 and SO2 are regulated as toxic chemicals.  No regulated flammable substances above the threshold quantity are used at the facility.

The maximum inventory of the aforementioned regulated substances is 93,000 pounds of NH3 stored in an aboveground storage tank.  The remaining quantity of regulated substance is as follows:  67,000 pounds of NH3, also stored in an aboveground storage tank.

3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Our facility has taken all the necessary ste

ps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with ASME B31.3.  A number of processes at our facility are subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.

Process Safety Information
Champion maintains a detailed record of process safety information that describes the hazards of regulated substances, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.  Much of this information was compiled during the preparation of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).

Process Hazard Analysis
Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  Champion primarily uses the checklist and HAZOP method analysis techniques to perform these evaluations.  The studies were undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and will revalidated at regular intervals.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Champion maintains written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the process safety.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turna

round.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Champion develops and implements safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; confined space entry; opening process equipment or piping; and control over entrance into a stationary source by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel.  These safe work practices apply to employees and contractor employees.

Training
Champion has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Initial training of operators is provided, and refresher training is provided as required.  Both initial and refresher training is documented and records of training are maintained onsite for at least 3 years.

Mechanical Integrity
Champion has written procedures for mantaining on-going integrity of process equipment, which incorporates training for process maintenance activities, inspection and testing, corrective action for equipment deficiencies, and the application of quality assurance measures.  Champion carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper installation and operation.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified and trained personnel.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  The plant also incorporates quality assurance measures to ensure that equipment and parts are suitable for the process application for which they will be used.

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Champion to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  These procedures will

be updated as needed.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes will be conducted as a regular practice at Champion.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications, and safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Champion conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out by at least one person knowledgeable in the process and are conducted at least every 3 years.  Audit findings are documented in a report.  Any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner and are also documented.  The facility will maintain the two most recent compliance audit report.

Incident Investigation
Champion promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  An incident investigation will be initiated as promptly as possible, but no later than 48 hours after the incident, and will involve at least one person knowledgeable of the process involved.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  A report will be prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and will included any resolutions and corrective action.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
Champion believes that PSM and accident prevention are a team effort.  Company employees are strongly e

ncouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

Hot Work Permit
Champion will issue a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.  The permit shall document that the fire prevention and protection requirements have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations; it shall indicate the date(s) authorized for hot work; and identify the object on which hot work is to be performed.  The permit will be kept on file until completion of the hot work operations.

Contractors
Champion hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Before any contractors are allowed to work at Champion, they undergo an orientation conducted by the PSM team.  During this orientation contractors are made aware of the known potential hazards related the contractor's work, the hazards of regulated substances within Champion, the safe work procedures insisted on by Champion, and familiarized with the Hot Work Permit Policy and the Lock Out/Tag Out procedures used at Champion.  Contractors are informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur, and this information includes evacuation routes and assembly points.  Champion will document that the contractor has received and understands the training.

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
The processes at Champion have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  Section 7 of the RMP describes existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances at the facility.  The accident preventio

n program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-regulated processes at Champion.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accidental scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human error.

4. Five-year Accident History
The facility has not experienced any reportable accidents in the past 5 years.

5. Emergency Response Program
Champion has a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials, which is in place to protect worker and public safety, and the environment.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  Employees receive training in emergency procedures.  To ensure proper functioning, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within processes that would require a modified emergency response.  The emergency plan has been coordinated with and verified by the Ector County the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

At all times there must be at least one employee either on the facility premises or on-call (i.e., available to respond to an emergency by reaching the facility within a short period of time) with the responsibility for coordinating all emergency response measures.  This emergency coordinator will be thoroughly familiar with all aspects of the facility's emergency response plan, all operations and activities at the facility, the location and characteristics of material/waste handled, the location of all records within the facility, and the facility layout.  In addition, this person will have the authority to commit the resources needed to carry out the emergency response plan.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Champion will continue to improve sa
fety at the facility through training.  No other upcoming events are planned to improve safety at this time.
